intro: Banisteria adenopoda f. subrotunda, commonly known as the waxy beggar-tick, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in spikes, typical of the genus Banisteria. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodland areas. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural study.
